Description: Lead dice or die; much eroded, numbers sunk, 3/8 inches sq.
Curator's comments: Six sided (cubic) dice are known from 7th century BC contexts, but were particularly popular during the Roman period (Cool 2016, 229-231). They are most commonly made of limestone with drilled pips, but were also made from faience, ivory, marble, pumice, metal and terracotta. Numerous examples were found at Naukratis (Thomas 2018). A lead parallel is known from Naukratis (World Museum, Liverpool, 9,9,86,119), and other examples are known from the Nile Delta in Egypt (1964,0107.81). Although lead dice are attested in Egypt, Thomas Burgon was also collecting objects from Italy, Greece and Turkey where dice are relatively commonly found in Hellenistic and Roman contexts. Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17. Thomas, R. 2017. Tools and weapons, in A. Villing, M. Bergeron, G.Bourogiannis, A. Johnston, F. Leclère, A. Masson and R. Thomas, Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt. The British Museum, Online Research Catalogue PR https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Thomas_Tools_and_Weapons.pdf
